trans-unit.source: Enable offline sync for your Azure Mobile App (iOS)
trans-unit.target: Enable offline sync for your Azure Mobile App (iOS)

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use App Service Mobile Apps to cache and sync offline data in your iOS application
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use App Service Mobile Apps to cache and sync offline data in your iOS application

trans-unit.source: Enable offline sync for your iOS mobile app
trans-unit.target: Enable offline sync for your iOS mobile app

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This tutorial covers the offline sync feature of Azure Mobile Apps for iOS.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial covers the offline sync feature of Azure Mobile Apps for iOS.

trans-unit.source: Offline sync allows end-users to interact with a mobile app—viewing, adding, or modifying data—even when there is no network connection.
trans-unit.target: Offline sync allows end-users to interact with a mobile app—viewing, adding, or modifying data—even when there is no network connection.

trans-unit.source: Changes are stored in a local database; once the device is back online, these changes are synced with the remote backend.
trans-unit.target: Changes are stored in a local database; once the device is back online, these changes are synced with the remote backend.

trans-unit.source: If this is your first experience with Azure Mobile Apps, you should first complete the tutorial [Create an iOS App].
trans-unit.target: If this is your first experience with Azure Mobile Apps, you should first complete the tutorial [Create an iOS App].

trans-unit.source: If you do not use the downloaded quick start server project, you must add the data access extension packages to your project.
trans-unit.target: If you do not use the downloaded quick start server project, you must add the data access extension packages to your project.

trans-unit.source: For more information about server extension packages, see <link><linkText>Work with the .NET backend server SDK for Azure Mobile Apps</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about server extension packages, see <link><linkText>Work with the .NET backend server SDK for Azure Mobile Apps</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about the offline sync feature, see the topic [Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps].
trans-unit.target: To learn more about the offline sync feature, see the topic [Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps].

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Review the client sync code
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Review the client sync code

trans-unit.source: The client project that you downloaded for the tutorial [Create an iOS App] already contains code supporting offline synchronization using a local Core Data-based database.
trans-unit.target: The client project that you downloaded for the tutorial [Create an iOS App] already contains code supporting offline synchronization using a local Core Data-based database.

trans-unit.source: This section is a summary of what is already included in the tutorial code.
trans-unit.target: This section is a summary of what is already included in the tutorial code.

trans-unit.source: For a conceptual overview of the feature, see [Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps].
trans-unit.target: For a conceptual overview of the feature, see [Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps].

trans-unit.source: The offline data sync sync feature of Azure Mobile Apps allows end users to interact with a local database when the network is not accessible.
trans-unit.target: The offline data sync sync feature of Azure Mobile Apps allows end users to interact with a local database when the network is not accessible.

trans-unit.source: To use these features in your app, you initialize the sync context of MSClient and reference a local store.
trans-unit.target: To use these features in your app, you initialize the sync context of MSClient and reference a local store.

trans-unit.source: Then reference your table through the MSSyncTable interface.
trans-unit.target: Then reference your table through the MSSyncTable interface.

trans-unit.source: In QSTodoService.m, notice the type of the member syncTable is MSSyncTable.
trans-unit.target: In QSTodoService.m, notice the type of the member syncTable is MSSyncTable.

trans-unit.source: Offline sync uses this sync table interface instead of MSTable.
trans-unit.target: Offline sync uses this sync table interface instead of MSTable.

trans-unit.source: When a sync table is used, all operations go to the local store and are only synchronized with the remote backend with explicit push and pull operations.
trans-unit.target: When a sync table is used, all operations go to the local store and are only synchronized with the remote backend with explicit push and pull operations.

trans-unit.source: To get a reference to a sync table, use the method syncTableWithName.
trans-unit.target: To get a reference to a sync table, use the method syncTableWithName.

trans-unit.source: To remove offline sync functionality, use tableWithName instead.
trans-unit.target: To remove offline sync functionality, use tableWithName instead.

trans-unit.source: Before any table operations can be performed, the local store must be initialized.
trans-unit.target: Before any table operations can be performed, the local store must be initialized.

trans-unit.source: This is the relevant code in the QSTodoService.init method:
trans-unit.target: This is the relevant code in the QSTodoService.init method:

trans-unit.source: This creates a local store using the interface MSCoreDataStore, which is provided in the Mobile Apps SDK.
trans-unit.target: This creates a local store using the interface MSCoreDataStore, which is provided in the Mobile Apps SDK.

trans-unit.source: You can instead a provide a different local store by implementing the MSSyncContextDataSource protocol.
trans-unit.target: You can instead a provide a different local store by implementing the MSSyncContextDataSource protocol.

trans-unit.source: The first parameter of initWithDelegate is used to specify a conflict handler.
trans-unit.target: The first parameter of initWithDelegate is used to specify a conflict handler.

trans-unit.source: Since we have passed nil, we will get the default conflict handler, which fails on any conflict.
trans-unit.target: Since we have passed nil, we will get the default conflict handler, which fails on any conflict.

trans-unit.source: The methods pullData and syncData performs the actual sync operation: syncData first pushes new changes, then calls pullData to get data from the remote backend.
trans-unit.target: The methods pullData and syncData performs the actual sync operation: syncData first pushes new changes, then calls pullData to get data from the remote backend.

trans-unit.source: In turn, the method pullData gets new data that matches a query:
trans-unit.target: In turn, the method pullData gets new data that matches a query:

trans-unit.source: In syncData, we first call pushWithCompletion on the sync context.
trans-unit.target: In syncData, we first call pushWithCompletion on the sync context.

trans-unit.source: This method is a member of MSSyncContext (rather than the sync table itself) because it will push changes across all tables.
trans-unit.target: This method is a member of MSSyncContext (rather than the sync table itself) because it will push changes across all tables.

trans-unit.source: Only records that have been modified in some way locally (through CUD operations) will be sent to the server.
trans-unit.target: Only records that have been modified in some way locally (through CUD operations) will be sent to the server.

trans-unit.source: Then the helper pullData is called, which calls MSSyncTable.pullWithQuery to retrieve remote data and store in the local database.
trans-unit.target: Then the helper pullData is called, which calls MSSyncTable.pullWithQuery to retrieve remote data and store in the local database.

trans-unit.source: Note that in this example, the push operation was not strictly necessary.
trans-unit.target: Note that in this example, the push operation was not strictly necessary.

trans-unit.source: If there are any changes pending in the sync context for the table that is doing a push operation, pull always issues a push first.
trans-unit.target: If there are any changes pending in the sync context for the table that is doing a push operation, pull always issues a push first.

trans-unit.source: However, if you have more than one sync table, it is best explicitly call push to ensure that everything is consistent across related tables.
trans-unit.target: However, if you have more than one sync table, it is best explicitly call push to ensure that everything is consistent across related tables.

trans-unit.source: The method pullWithQuery allows you to specify a query to filter the records you wish to retrieve.
trans-unit.target: The method pullWithQuery allows you to specify a query to filter the records you wish to retrieve.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the query just retrieves all records in the remote TodoItem table.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the query just retrieves all records in the remote TodoItem table.

trans-unit.source: The second parameter to pullWithQuery is a query ID that is used for incremental sync.
trans-unit.target: The second parameter to pullWithQuery is a query ID that is used for incremental sync.

trans-unit.source: Incremental sync retrieves only those records modified since the last sync, using the record's UpdatedAt timestamp (called ms_updatedAt in the local store).
trans-unit.target: Incremental sync retrieves only those records modified since the last sync, using the record's UpdatedAt timestamp (called ms_updatedAt in the local store).

trans-unit.source: The query ID should be a descriptive string that is unique for each logical query in your app.
trans-unit.target: The query ID should be a descriptive string that is unique for each logical query in your app.

trans-unit.source: To opt-out of incremental sync, pass nil as the query ID.
trans-unit.target: To opt-out of incremental sync, pass nil as the query ID.

trans-unit.source: Note that this can be potentially inefficient, since it will retrieve all records on each pull operation.
trans-unit.target: Note that this can be potentially inefficient, since it will retrieve all records on each pull operation.

trans-unit.source: In the class QSTodoService, the method syncData is called after the operations that modify data, addItem and completeItem.
trans-unit.target: In the class QSTodoService, the method syncData is called after the operations that modify data, addItem and completeItem.

trans-unit.source: It is also called from QSTodoListViewController.refresh, so that the user gets the latest data whenever they perform the refresh gesture.
trans-unit.target: It is also called from QSTodoListViewController.refresh, so that the user gets the latest data whenever they perform the refresh gesture.

trans-unit.source: The app also performs a sync on launch, since QSTodoListViewController.init calls refresh.
trans-unit.target: The app also performs a sync on launch, since QSTodoListViewController.init calls refresh.

trans-unit.source: Because syncData is called whenever data is modified, this app assumes that the user is online whenever they are editing data.
trans-unit.target: Because syncData is called whenever data is modified, this app assumes that the user is online whenever they are editing data.

trans-unit.source: In another section, we will update the app so that users can edit even when they are offline.
trans-unit.target: In another section, we will update the app so that users can edit even when they are offline.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Review the Core Data model
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Review the Core Data model

trans-unit.source: When using the Core Data offline store, you need to define particular tables and fields in your data model.
trans-unit.target: When using the Core Data offline store, you need to define particular tables and fields in your data model.

trans-unit.source: The sample app already includes a data model with the right format.
trans-unit.target: The sample app already includes a data model with the right format.

trans-unit.source: In this section we will walk through these tables and how they are used.
trans-unit.target: In this section we will walk through these tables and how they are used.

trans-unit.source: Open QSDataModel.xcdatamodeld.
trans-unit.target: Open QSDataModel.xcdatamodeld.

trans-unit.source: There are four tables defined--three that are used by the SDK, and one table for the todo items themselves:
trans-unit.target: There are four tables defined--three that are used by the SDK, and one table for the todo items themselves:

trans-unit.source: * MS_TableOperations: For tracking the items that need to be synchronized with the server
trans-unit.target: * MS_TableOperations: For tracking the items that need to be synchronized with the server

trans-unit.source: * MS_TableOperationErrors: For tracking any errors that happen during offline synchronization
trans-unit.target: * MS_TableOperationErrors: For tracking any errors that happen during offline synchronization

trans-unit.source: * MS_TableConfig: For tracking the last updated time for the last sync operation for all pull operations
trans-unit.target: * MS_TableConfig: For tracking the last updated time for the last sync operation for all pull operations

trans-unit.source: * TodoItem: For storing the todo items.
trans-unit.target: * TodoItem: For storing the todo items.

trans-unit.source: The system columns ms_createdAt, ms_updatedAt, and ms_version are optional system properties.
trans-unit.target: The system columns ms_createdAt, ms_updatedAt, and ms_version are optional system properties.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Mobile Apps SDK reserves column names that being with "**ms_**".
trans-unit.target: The Azure Mobile Apps SDK reserves column names that being with "**ms_**".

trans-unit.source: You should not use this prefix on anything other than system columns, otherwise your column names will be modified when using the remote backend.
trans-unit.target: You should not use this prefix on anything other than system columns, otherwise your column names will be modified when using the remote backend.

trans-unit.source: When using the offline sync feature, you must define the system tables as shown below.
trans-unit.target: When using the offline sync feature, you must define the system tables as shown below.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Change the sync behavior of the app
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Change the sync behavior of the app

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will modify the app so that it does not sync on app start, or when inserting and updating items, but only when the refresh gesture button is performed.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will modify the app so that it does not sync on app start, or when inserting and updating items, but only when the refresh gesture button is performed.

trans-unit.source: In QSTodoListViewController.m, change the viewDidLoad method to remove the call to [self refresh] at the end of the method.
trans-unit.target: In QSTodoListViewController.m, change the viewDidLoad method to remove the call to [self refresh] at the end of the method.

trans-unit.source: Now, the data will not be synced with the server on app start, but instead will be the contents of local store.
trans-unit.target: Now, the data will not be synced with the server on app start, but instead will be the contents of local store.

trans-unit.source: In QSTodoService.m, modify the definition of addItem so that it doesn't sync after the item is inserted.
trans-unit.target: In QSTodoService.m, modify the definition of addItem so that it doesn't sync after the item is inserted.

trans-unit.source: Remove the self syncData block and replace with the following:
trans-unit.target: Remove the self syncData block and replace with the following:

trans-unit.source: Modify the definition of completeItem as above; remove the block for self syncData and replace with the following:
trans-unit.target: Modify the definition of completeItem as above; remove the block for self syncData and replace with the following:

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Test the app
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Test the app

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will turn of Wi-Fi in the simulator to create an offline scenario.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will turn of Wi-Fi in the simulator to create an offline scenario.

trans-unit.source: When you add data items, they will be held in the local Core Data store, but not synced to the mobile backend.
trans-unit.target: When you add data items, they will be held in the local Core Data store, but not synced to the mobile backend.

trans-unit.source: Turn off Wi-Fi in the iOS simulator.
trans-unit.target: Turn off Wi-Fi in the iOS simulator.

trans-unit.source: Add some todo items or complete some items.
trans-unit.target: Add some todo items or complete some items.

trans-unit.source: Quit the simulator (or forcibly close the app) and restart.
trans-unit.target: Quit the simulator (or forcibly close the app) and restart.

trans-unit.source: Verify that your changes have been persisted.
trans-unit.target: Verify that your changes have been persisted.

trans-unit.source: View the contents of the remote TodoItem table:
trans-unit.target: View the contents of the remote TodoItem table:

trans-unit.source: For the JavaScript backend, to to the Management Portal, and click the Data tab to view the contents of the TodoItem table.
trans-unit.target: For the JavaScript backend, to to the Management Portal, and click the Data tab to view the contents of the TodoItem table.

trans-unit.source: For the .NET backend, view the table contents either with a SQL tool such as SQL Server Management Studio, or a REST client such as Fiddler or Postman.
trans-unit.target: For the .NET backend, view the table contents either with a SQL tool such as SQL Server Management Studio, or a REST client such as Fiddler or Postman.

trans-unit.source: Verify that the new items have not been synced to the server:
trans-unit.target: Verify that the new items have not been synced to the server:

trans-unit.source: Turn on the Wi-Fi in the iOS simulator, then perform the refresh gesture by pulling down the list of items.
trans-unit.target: Turn on the Wi-Fi in the iOS simulator, then perform the refresh gesture by pulling down the list of items.

trans-unit.source: You will see a progress spinner and the text "Syncing...".
trans-unit.target: You will see a progress spinner and the text "Syncing...".

trans-unit.source: View the TodoItem data again.
trans-unit.target: View the TodoItem data again.

trans-unit.source: The new and changed TodoItems should now appear.
trans-unit.target: The new and changed TodoItems should now appear.

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: In order to support the offline sync feature, we used the MSSyncTable interface and initialized MSClient.syncContext with a local store.
trans-unit.target: In order to support the offline sync feature, we used the MSSyncTable interface and initialized MSClient.syncContext with a local store.

trans-unit.source: In this case the local store was a Core Data-based database.
trans-unit.target: In this case the local store was a Core Data-based database.

trans-unit.source: When using a Core Data local store, you must define several tables with the <link><linkText>correct system properties</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: When using a Core Data local store, you must define several tables with the <link><linkText>correct system properties</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The normal CRUD operations for Azure Mobile Apps work as if the app is still connected but all the operations occur against the local store.
trans-unit.target: The normal CRUD operations for Azure Mobile Apps work as if the app is still connected but all the operations occur against the local store.

trans-unit.source: When we wanted to synchronize the local store with the server, we used the MSSyncTable.pullWithQuery and MSClient.syncContext.pushWithCompletion methods.
trans-unit.target: When we wanted to synchronize the local store with the server, we used the MSSyncTable.pullWithQuery and MSClient.syncContext.pushWithCompletion methods.

trans-unit.source: To push changes to the server, we called pushWithCompletion.
trans-unit.target: To push changes to the server, we called pushWithCompletion.

trans-unit.source: This method is a member of MSSyncContext instead of the sync table because it will push changes across all tables.
trans-unit.target: This method is a member of MSSyncContext instead of the sync table because it will push changes across all tables.

trans-unit.source: Only records that have been modified in some way locally (through CUD operations) will be sent to the server.
trans-unit.target: Only records that have been modified in some way locally (through CUD operations) will be sent to the server.

trans-unit.source: To pull data from a table on the server to the app, we called MSSyncTable.pullWithQuery.
trans-unit.target: To pull data from a table on the server to the app, we called MSSyncTable.pullWithQuery.

trans-unit.source: A pull always issues a push first.
trans-unit.target: A pull always issues a push first.

trans-unit.source: This is to ensure all tables in the local store along with relationships remain consistent.
trans-unit.target: This is to ensure all tables in the local store along with relationships remain consistent.

trans-unit.source: Note that pullWithQuery can by used to filter the data that is stored on the client, by customizing the query parameter.
trans-unit.target: Note that pullWithQuery can by used to filter the data that is stored on the client, by customizing the query parameter.

trans-unit.source: To enable incremental sync, pass a query ID to pullWithQuery.
trans-unit.target: To enable incremental sync, pass a query ID to pullWithQuery.

trans-unit.source: The query ID is used to store the last updated timestamp from the results of the last pull operation.
trans-unit.target: The query ID is used to store the last updated timestamp from the results of the last pull operation.

trans-unit.source: The query ID should be a descriptive string that is unique for each logical query in your app.
trans-unit.target: The query ID should be a descriptive string that is unique for each logical query in your app.

trans-unit.source: If the query has a parameter, then the same parameter value has to be part of the query ID.
trans-unit.target: If the query has a parameter, then the same parameter value has to be part of the query ID.

trans-unit.source: If you want to opt out of incremental sync, pass nil as the query ID.
trans-unit.target: If you want to opt out of incremental sync, pass nil as the query ID.

trans-unit.source: In this case, all records will be retrieved on every call to pullWithQuery, which is potentially inefficient.
trans-unit.target: In this case, all records will be retrieved on every call to pullWithQuery, which is potentially inefficient.

trans-unit.source: Additional Resources
trans-unit.target: Additional Resources

trans-unit.source: [Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps]
trans-unit.target: [Offline Data Sync in Azure Mobile Apps]

trans-unit.target: [Cloud Cover: Offline Sync in Azure Mobile Services] \(note: the video is on Mobile Services, but offline sync works in a similar way in Azure Mobile Apps\)

trans-unit.target: test
